editorial:
(Author & Analysis: SpyrosAliv) SolutionIf then we can output any
permutation, since in order for the to be equal to , every value must
appear. Otherwise, we want to build a permutation such that two main
conditions hold.Firstly, we want to appear on the final strip as soon as
possible. In other words, the first index such that must be minimized.
In addition, the index such that must be maximized, since the of a set
that contains cannot be equal to .There are a lot of constructions that
satisfy those conditions. One of them is the permutation .
name: B. St. Chroma
statement:
Given a permutation^{
text{ }} p of length n that contains every integer from 0 to n-1 and a
strip of n cells, St. Chroma will paint the i-th cell of the strip in
the color
operatorname{MEX}(p_1, p_2, ..., p_i)^{
text{ }}.For example, suppose p = [1, 0, 3, 2]. Then, St. Chroma will
paint the cells of the strip in the following way: [0, 2, 2, 4].You have
been given two integers n and x. Because St. Chroma loves color x,
construct a permutation p such that the number of cells in the strip
that are painted color x is .^{
text{ }}A permutation of length n is a sequence of n elements that
contains every integer from 0 to n-1 exactly once. For example, [0, 3,
1, 2] is a permutation, but [1, 2, 0, 1] isn’t since 1 appears twice,
and [1, 3, 2] isn’t since 0 does not appear at all.^{
text{ }}The
operatorname{MEX} of a sequence is defined as the first non-negative
integer that does not appear in it. For example,
operatorname{MEX}(1, 3, 0, 2) = 4, and
operatorname{MEX}(3, 1, 2) = 0.
